elements.content: This study describes the selective synthesis of linear, trinuclear, halide-bridged CuI complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+ (1a: X = Cl; 1b: X = Br; 1c: X = I) stabilized by the tridentate dpmp ligand obtained by self-assembly reactions in THF/MeCN. Upon drying, the MeCN ligands can be removed and the complexes are transformed to the reactive parent trinuclear [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (2a–c) building blocks with two vacant coordination sites on the terminal Cu atoms. Another synthesis in CH2Cl2 directly yields 2a–c. Additionally, two related isomeric compounds, 2a* and 2c*, and two CH2Cl2-ligated complexes, [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(CH2Cl2)2]+ (X = Br (3b), I (3c)), were structurally characterized. The frameworks of the cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complexes are stable in solution at low temperatures and show dynamic coordination behavior at elevated temperatures, indicated by new signals arising in the 31P­{1H} NMR spectra. This evolution cannot be shifted back by decreasing the temperature again. However, cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (X = Cl, Br, I) complexes can be obtained selectively in the solid state upon crystallization. Although reactions of 2a–c with complexes [{CpMo­(CO)2}2(μ,η2:η2-E2)] (E = P (A1), As (A2)) led to unsymmetrically substituted [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(η1-L)]+ (4a–c: X = Cl–I, L = A1; 5: X = Cl, L = A2) complexes, reactions with the cyclo-P3 complex [CpMo­(CO)2(η3-P3)] (B) afforded zigzag chain polymers [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(μ,η1:η1-B)] n [BF4] n (6a: X = Cl; 6b: X = Br) and symmetrically substituted complex [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2(η1-B)2]+ (7). Reactions of 2a–c with cyclo-E5 complexes [Cp*Fe­(η5-E5)] (E = P (C1), As (C2)) led to the isolation of one-dimensional coordination polymers [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(μ,η1:η1-L)] n [BF4] n (8a–b: X = Cl–Br, L = C1; 9: X = Cl, L = C2) and symmetrically substituted complex [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2(η1-C1)2]+ (10). All products exhibit a trinuclear, cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex as the central structural motif. Variation of the intramolecular Cu–Cu distances inside the Cu3 complexes is discussed, and supporting DFT computations for the model complex [Cu3(μ-Cl)2(dmmp)2{(η1-A1)}]+ (4a′) are presented.

elements.content: A simple, one-pot synthesis of trinuclear [Cu3] building blocks with a polyphosphine ligand was developed. These multimetallic complexes have a linear structure, and their Cu−Cu distances are influenced by coordination of additional ligands. By introducing P n and As n ligand complexes, a variety of finite and polymeric coordination compounds with [Cu3] units could be isolated.

These multimetallic complexes have a linear structure, and their Cu-Cu distances are influenced by coordination of additional ligands. By introducing P n  and As n  ligand complexes, a variety of finite and polymeric coordination compounds with [Cu3] units could be isolated.

elements.content: Extended linear arrays of transition metals have been discussed for their potential application in molecular electronics. The majority of these linear metal chains feature various supporting ligands (). The most famous and thoroughly studied group of extended metal atom chains (EMACs) includes up to 11 metal atoms (homo- or heterometallic) in one linear array containing polypyridylamide ligands or their derivatives (, I). Molecular chains of Pd atoms can be stabilized by neutral unsaturated or aromatic organic ligands (, II). Polydentate phosphines like the tridentate ligand bis­(diphenyl­phosphinomethyl)­phenylphosphine (dpmp; ) can also stabilize multimetallic complexes of Au, Ag, Rh, and Pt, including the formation of hexanuclear Pt string complexes. Utilization of the analogous tetraphosphine ligand gave access to heterometallic trinuclear complexes as well as linear chains of four M+ (M = Ag, Au) cations (, III) and multinuclear complexes of up to eight metal centers. Recently, it was demonstrated that hydride-bridged CuI complexes stabilized by tetraphosphine ligands undergo facile CO2 insertion. In 1992, the preparation of trinuclear, halide-bridged CuI complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+ (X = Cl, I) was reported (, IV). Although the intermolecular Cu–Cu distance of 3.3 Å does not suggest metal–metal interactions, these complexes exhibit photoluminescence in the solid state and may be valuable building blocks in supramolecular chemistry. In 2009, the analogous tetranuclear complexes were also prepared. The main challenge in the chemistry of molecular metal chains lies in the development of rational synthetic methods based on self-assembly that lead to linear arrays instead of polyhedral clusters or product mixtures. Another intriguing goal is the introduction of additional ligands of varying nature to the terminal metal atoms in order to form heteroleptic linear metal clusters or extended coordination polymers in a controllable manner. Therefore, the current investigation includes the introduction of organometallic E n ligand complexes A1–C2 () that contain substituent-free pnictogen atoms (E = P, As) to preassembled CuI arrays. It was shown that these E n ligand complexes are excellent multidentate ligands for supramolecular chemistry, allowing a wide variety of possible coordination modes to be accessed. Reactions of cyclo-P5 complex C1 with CuI halides result in the formation of coordination polymers and spherical supramolecules, which are referred to as “inorganic fullerenes” due to their analogous topology. When [CpRFe­(η5-P5)] complexes with sterically demanding Cp ligands (CpBn = C5(CH2Ph)5, CpBIG = C5(4- n Bu-C6H4)5 ) are reacted with CuI halides, highly soluble and very large supramolecules are obtained. P2 complex A1 readily forms homoleptic dinuclear complexes [M2(A1)4]2+ with monovalent cations M+ (M = Cu, Ag, Au), and these exhibit dynamic coordination behavior in solution. Addition of organic linker molecules to solutions of these complexes gives access to heteroleptic organometallic–organic hybrid materials, forming polymers, extended frameworks, or isolated rectangles. Additionally, it was demonstrated that introduction of A1 to di- and trinuclear CuI complexes containing bridging mixed P,N ligands or polyphosphine ligands affords original coordination modes for A1 without the collapse of the preassembled multimetallic fragments. Utilization of the weakly coordinating anion [Al­{OC­(CF3)3}4]− enables the isolation and characterization of a variety of compounds that show the highly dynamic coordination behavior of E n ligand complexes toward Lewis acidic cations Cu+, Ag+, Tl+, In+, and Ga+.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Extended linear arrays of transition metals have been discussed for their potential application in molecular electronics. The majority of these linear metal chains feature various supporting ligands (). The most famous and thoroughly studied group of extended metal atom chains (EMACs) includes up to 11 metal atoms (homo- or heterometallic) in one linear array containing polypyridylamide ligands or their derivatives (, I). Molecular chains of Pd atoms can be stabilized by neutral unsaturated or aromatic organic ligands (, II). Polydentate phosphines like the tridentate ligand bis(diphenylphosphinomethyl)phenylphosphine (dpmp; ) can also stabilize multimetallic complexes of Au, Ag, Rh, and Pt, including the formation of hexanuclear Pt string complexes. Utilization of the analogous tetraphosphine ligand gave access to heterometallic trinuclear complexes as well as linear chains of four M+ (M = Ag, Au) cations (, III) and multinuclear complexes of up to eight metal centers. Recently, it was demonstrated that hydride-bridged CuI complexes stabilized by tetraphosphine ligands undergo facile CO2 insertion. In 1992, the preparation of trinuclear, halide-bridged CuI complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+ (X = Cl, I) was reported (, IV). Although the intermolecular Cu-Cu distance of 3.3 Å does not suggest metal-metal interactions, these complexes exhibit photoluminescence in the solid state and may be valuable building blocks in supramolecular chemistry. In 2009, the analogous tetranuclear complexes were also prepared. The main challenge in the chemistry of molecular metal chains lies in the development of rational synthetic methods based on self-assembly that lead to linear arrays instead of polyhedral clusters or product mixtures. Another intriguing goal is the introduction of additional ligands of varying nature to the terminal metal atoms in order to form heteroleptic linear metal clusters or extended coordination polymers in a controllable manner. Therefore, the current investigation includes the introduction of organometallic E n  ligand complexes A1-C2 () that contain substituent-free pnictogen atoms (E = P, As) to preassembled CuI arrays. It was shown that these E n  ligand complexes are excellent multidentate ligands for supramolecular chemistry, allowing a wide variety of possible coordination modes to be accessed. Reactions of cyclo-P5 complex C1 with CuI halides result in the formation of coordination polymers and spherical supramolecules, which are referred to as "inorganic fullerenes" due to their analogous topology. When [CpRFe(η5-P5)] complexes with sterically demanding Cp ligands (CpBn = C5(CH2Ph)5, CpBIG = C5(4- n Bu-C6H4)5 ) are reacted with CuI halides, highly soluble and very large supramolecules are obtained. P2 complex A1 readily forms homoleptic dinuclear complexes [M2(A1)4]2+ with monovalent cations M+ (M = Cu, Ag, Au), and these exhibit dynamic coordination behavior in solution. Addition of organic linker molecules to solutions of these complexes gives access to heteroleptic organometallic-organic hybrid materials, forming polymers, extended frameworks, or isolated rectangles. Additionally, it was demonstrated that introduction of A1 to di- and trinuclear CuI complexes containing bridging mixed P,N ligands or polyphosphine ligands affords original coordination modes for A1 without the collapse of the preassembled multimetallic fragments. Utilization of the weakly coordinating anion [Al{OC(CF3)3}4]- enables the isolation and characterization of a variety of compounds that show the highly dynamic coordination behavior of E n  ligand complexes toward Lewis acidic cations Cu+, Ag+, Tl+, In+, and Ga+.

Linear Metal Chains Featuring Various Supporting Ligands<xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

(I) Model complexes of linear transition metal arrays supported by polypyridylamide ligands, (II) Pd chains sandwiched by conjugated polyene molecules, (III) polymetallic Ag+ and Au+ clusters stabilized by polyphosphine ligands, and (IV) multinuclear CuI chains stabilized by polyphosphine ligands and bridging halides.

elements.content: The current study focuses on trinuclear CuI complexes (, IV), stabilized by the tridentate phosphine ligand dpmp (), and their reactivity. Herein, we describe a simple, straightforward synthesis of trinuclear, cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+ (X = Cl, Br, I) complexes 1a–c containing terminal MeCN ligands. It is shown that the terminal MeCN ligands can be removed and that these derivatives can be easily transformed to [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ 2a–c cationic units exhibiting two vacant terminal coordination sites. Additionally, a direct synthesis of 2a–c is presented. These reactive trinuclear complexes were investigated by VT-NMR experiments to gain additional insight into the existing species in solution. Subsequently, the coordination chemistry of E n ligand complexes A1–C2 toward the parent trinuclear complexes is investigated. The results of this study, which have been partly reported in a preliminary communication, give access to a rational synthesis of discrete and infinite supramolecular compounds containing the linear parent trinuclear CuI building blocks [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ and enable the possibility of directly comparing the coordination behavior of P n and their analogous As n ligand complexes.
elements.clean_text: The current study focuses on trinuclear CuI complexes (, IV), stabilized by the tridentate phosphine ligand dpmp (), and their reactivity. Herein, we describe a simple, straightforward synthesis of trinuclear, cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+ (X = Cl, Br, I) complexes 1a-c containing terminal MeCN ligands. It is shown that the terminal MeCN ligands can be removed and that these derivatives can be easily transformed to [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ 2a-c cationic units exhibiting two vacant terminal coordination sites. Additionally, a direct synthesis of 2a-c is presented. These reactive trinuclear complexes were investigated by VT-NMR experiments to gain additional insight into the existing species in solution. Subsequently, the coordination chemistry of E n  ligand complexes A1-C2 toward the parent trinuclear complexes is investigated. The results of this study, which have been partly reported in a preliminary communication, give access to a rational synthesis of discrete and infinite supramolecular compounds containing the linear parent trinuclear CuI building blocks [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ and enable the possibility of directly comparing the coordination behavior of P n  and their analogous As n  ligand complexes.

elements.content: The [Cu3(μ-Cl)2(dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+ complex cation was previously prepared as the [ClO4]− salt after recrystallization of the crude product obtained from heating dpmp and CuCl in MeOH at 60 °C and subsequent metathesis with LiClO4. Herein, we present a simple synthesis () based on self-assembly under mild conditions to yield trinuclear complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+ (X = Cl (1a), Br (1b), I (1c)) as [BF4]− salts as the only products in good yields (65–80%). Dissolution of 2 equiv of CuX (X = Cl, Br, I), 2 equiv of dpmp, and 1 equiv of [Cu­(MeCN)4]­[BF4] in a THF/MeCN (80:20) mixture affords clear colorless solutions within a few minutes. Diffusion of Et2O into the filtered solutions affords colorless single crystals, which were used to establish the X-ray structures of 1a–c. Elemental analysis reveals the complete removal of the terminal MeCN ligands upon drying in vacuum overnight at room temperature. This gives access to parent complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (X = Cl (2a), Br (2b), I (2c)) as colorless powders in the solid state. Our investigations revealed an increased reactivity of 2a–c compared to that of 1a–c as the relatively weak E n ligand complexes were not able to substitute the terminal MeCN ligands of 1a–c in THF/MeCN solutions. Therefore, we subsequently developed a direct synthesis of 2a–c in CH2Cl2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Parent Cu3 Complexes

Synthesis of 1a-c 

The [Cu3(μ-Cl)2(dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+ complex cation was previously prepared as the [ClO4]- salt after recrystallization of the crude product obtained from heating dpmp and CuCl in MeOH at 60 °C and subsequent metathesis with LiClO4. Herein, we present a simple synthesis () based on self-assembly under mild conditions to yield trinuclear complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+ (X = Cl (1a), Br (1b), I (1c)) as [BF4]- salts as the only products in good yields (65-80%). Dissolution of 2 equiv of CuX (X = Cl, Br, I), 2 equiv of dpmp, and 1 equiv of [Cu(MeCN)4][BF4] in a THF/MeCN (80:20) mixture affords clear colorless solutions within a few minutes. Diffusion of Et2O into the filtered solutions affords colorless single crystals, which were used to establish the X-ray structures of 1a-c. Elemental analysis reveals the complete removal of the terminal MeCN ligands upon drying in vacuum overnight at room temperature. This gives access to parent complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (X = Cl (2a), Br (2b), I (2c)) as colorless powders in the solid state. Our investigations revealed an increased reactivity of 2a-c compared to that of 1a-c as the relatively weak E n  ligand complexes were not able to substitute the terminal MeCN ligands of 1a-c in THF/MeCN solutions. Therefore, we subsequently developed a direct synthesis of 2a-c in CH2Cl2.

elements.content: When the reactants (2 equiv of CuX (X = Cl, Br, I), 2 equiv of dpmp, and 1 equiv of [Cu­(MeCN)4]­[BF4]) are suspended in pure CH2Cl2 or ortho-difluorobenzene (o-DFB) and stirred at room temperature, the formation of clear colorless solutions can be observed after 5 min (X = Cl), 30 min (X = Br), or 5–6 h (X = I). Subsequent diffusion of alkanes into the filtered solution yields parent trinuclear complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (X = Cl (2a), Br (2b), I (2c)) as colorless crystals in good yields (65–75%). Additionally, [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(CH2Cl2)2]+ (X = Br (3b), I (3c)) (identified by single-crystal X-ray structural analysis), which show two terminal η1-coordinating CH2Cl2 molecules, could also be observed from these reactions. These CH2Cl2 solvent molecules are removed by drying the crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Direct Synthesis of 2a-c 

When the reactants (2 equiv of CuX (X = Cl, Br, I), 2 equiv of dpmp, and 1 equiv of [Cu(MeCN)4][BF4]) are suspended in pure CH2Cl2 or ortho-difluorobenzene (o-DFB) and stirred at room temperature, the formation of clear colorless solutions can be observed after 5 min (X = Cl), 30 min (X = Br), or 5-6 h (X = I). Subsequent diffusion of alkanes into the filtered solution yields parent trinuclear complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (X = Cl (2a), Br (2b), I (2c)) as colorless crystals in good yields (65-75%). Additionally, [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(CH2Cl2)2]+ (X = Br (3b), I (3c)) (identified by single-crystal X-ray structural analysis), which show two terminal η1-coordinating CH2Cl2 molecules, could also be observed from these reactions. These CH2Cl2 solvent molecules are removed by drying the crystals.

elements.content:
1a–c contain terminal MeCN ligands; 2a–c, 3b, and 3c contain two coordinating CH2Cl2 solvent molecules. Yields are given in parentheses.

X-ray Structural Analysis of <bold>1a</bold>–<bold>3c</bold>

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis (a) clearly reveals that monocationic 1a–c bearing [BF4]− as the counterion have very similar structures for their central trinuclear CuI complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+. These discrete alignments of three CuI centers are stabilized by two bridging dpmp ligands and two additional bridging halide anions in the molecular backbone. The coordination environment of all Cu atoms in 1a–c can be described as distorted tetrahedral. The distances of the MeCN ligands toward the terminal Cu atoms are very similar for 1a–c, ∼2.06 Å, except for N1–Cu1 in 1a which is slightly longer, 2.1425(1) Å. The intramolecular Cu–Cu distances in the MeCN-ligated complexes 1a–c are too long for d10–d10 metallophilic interactions (3.2330(1)–3.4388(1) Å) and increase with the size of the halides from 1a–c. The Cu3 chains can be viewed as almost linear with Cu–Cu–Cu angles between 163 and 165°.

a  1a-c contain terminal MeCN ligands; 2a-c, 3b, and 3c contain two coordinating CH2Cl2 solvent molecules. Yields are given in parentheses.  

X-ray Structural Analysis of 1a-3c 

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis (a) clearly reveals that monocationic 1a-c bearing [BF4]- as the counterion have very similar structures for their central trinuclear CuI complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+. These discrete alignments of three CuI centers are stabilized by two bridging dpmp ligands and two additional bridging halide anions in the molecular backbone. The coordination environment of all Cu atoms in 1a-c can be described as distorted tetrahedral. The distances of the MeCN ligands toward the terminal Cu atoms are very similar for 1a-c, ~2.06 Å, except for N1-Cu1 in 1a which is slightly longer, 2.1425(1) Å. The intramolecular Cu-Cu distances in the MeCN-ligated complexes 1a-c are too long for d10-d10 metallophilic interactions (3.2330(1)-3.4388(1) Å) and increase with the size of the halides from 1a-c. The Cu3 chains can be viewed as almost linear with Cu-Cu-Cu angles between 163 and 165°.

elements.content: Parent compounds [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ 2a–c are obtained either by removal of the terminal MeCN ligands from 1a–c or from direct synthesis in CH2Cl2 solutions. In the latter case, two different isomers of the central Cu3 building blocks [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ can be present (2a–c and 2a*–c*, respectively), which are related to each other by a slightly different configuration of one dpmp ligand. Among the six possible isomers, four of them could be structurally characterized during this study, 2a, 2a*, 2b, and 2c*, which will be discussed together. It has to be noted that for all compounds containing any terminal ligands only one isomer of the parent Cu3 building blocks (corresponding to 2a–c) is observed. The crystal structures of 2a, 2b, and 2c* are depicted in b, whereas 2a* is shown in a. The removal of the terminal MeCN ligands of 1a–b results in a drastic shortening of the intramolecular Cu–Cu distances in 2a (2.7827(5)–2.8244(4) Å) and 2b (2.8470(1)–2.8995(1) Å), whereas the general arrangement of the central cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (X = Cl, Br) complex is preserved. Similar short Cu–Cu distances are observed for 2a* and 2c*. summarizes all observed intramolecular Cu–Cu distances for the described compounds. The aforementioned Cu–Cu distances are within the expected range for possible d10–d10 metallophilic interactions of CuI. The central Cu atom exhibits a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment. In contrast, the terminal Cu atoms show a distorted trigonal planar coordination environment. The Cu–Cu–Cu angles of 2a and 2b are close to 163°, whereas they are a little smaller and close to 159° for 2a* and 2c*.

elements.content: The crystal structures of 3b and 3c are illustrated in b,c. The complexes contain a central [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (X = Br (3b), I (3c)) building block that shows two terminal CH2Cl2 molecules in a η1-coordination mode. The intramolecular Cu–Cu distances of 3b and 3c are slightly elongated (∼0.1 Å) compared to those of parent compounds 2b and 2c*. However, they are notably shorter (∼0.5 Å) compared to those observed in MeCN-ligated complexes 1b and 1c. The resulting Cu–Cl distances are rather long (∼3.2–3.3 Å), except for Cu1–Cl1 in 3b, which is only 2.8765(1) Å. The Cu–Cu–Cu angles of 3b and 3c are close to 163°.

When crystals of 1a–c are dried in vacuum, the terminal MeCN ligands can be removed completely, as proved by elemental analysis. Although heating or grinding the samples leads to a mixture of products (visible in the 31P­{1H} NMR spectrum at low temperature), drying in vacuum for several hours at room temperature cleanly converts MeCN-ligated complexes 1a–c directly to 2a–c in the solid state without destroying the central cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex. The solvent loss turns the crystals of 1a–c to fine powders of 2a–c. This can be concluded from the observed behavior of the dried samples of 1a–c in VT-NMR experiments shown in . When the powders of 2a–c (obtained from drying 1a–c) are dissolved at −80 °C in cold CD2Cl2, the 1H NMR spectra of 2a–c each show two broad signals for the diastereotopic H atoms HA and HB of the four chemically equivalent CH2 groups illustrated in . The 31P­{1H} NMR spectra of 2a–c show two broad signals in a 2:1 ratio for the RPPh2 (PA) and R′2PPh (PB) groups, respectively. When the samples are warmed in the spectrometer, the formation of new signals in the 1H as well as the 31P­{1H} NMR spectra of 2a–c can be observed above 253 K, which is caused by an increase in dynamic processes of the complex cations in solution. The 31P­{1H} NMR spectra of 2a–c at 300 K can be viewed as characteristic since they do not change significantly upon the addition of E n ligands (see below). Notably, these thermal evolutions are not reversible as upon cooling from room temperature solutions, i.e., the NMR spectra do not evolve and return to the initial pattern. This suggests equilibria of different species in solution. However, the NMR spectra of 2a and 2b at room temperature still show the initial signal patterns of the parent [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complexes (X = Cl (2a), Br (2b)) as the major species (∼80%). For X = I (2c), the initial signals of [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (2c) can still be observed at room temperature, although they represent only about 50% or less of the species in solution. It has to be emphasized at this point that by following our synthetic strategy of preassembled [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks no other combination of CuX, dpmp, and [Cu+]­[BF4] was ever observed in the solid sate. The observed behavior can be rationalized as follows: the equilibria of different species in solution include slow transformation processes that are almost frozen at low temperatures, and during the crystallization process, these equilibria are shifted to the side of the cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex. Unfortunately, the solid-state 31P­{1H} NMR spectra of parent complexes 2a–c show only one broad resonance in each case arising from several overlapping signals, and no assignment to the corresponding phosphorus atoms is possible (see Supporting Information).

NMR Characterization of Parent Complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ 2a-c in Solution

When crystals of 1a-c are dried in vacuum, the terminal MeCN ligands can be removed completely, as proved by elemental analysis. Although heating or grinding the samples leads to a mixture of products (visible in the 31P{1H} NMR spectrum at low temperature), drying in vacuum for several hours at room temperature cleanly converts MeCN-ligated complexes 1a-c directly to 2a-c in the solid state without destroying the central cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex. The solvent loss turns the crystals of 1a-c to fine powders of 2a-c. This can be concluded from the observed behavior of the dried samples of 1a-c in VT-NMR experiments shown in . When the powders of 2a-c (obtained from drying 1a-c) are dissolved at -80 °C in cold CD2Cl2, the 1H NMR spectra of 2a-c each show two broad signals for the diastereotopic H atoms HA and HB of the four chemically equivalent CH2 groups illustrated in . The 31P{1H} NMR spectra of 2a-c show two broad signals in a 2:1 ratio for the RPPh2 (PA) and R'2PPh (PB) groups, respectively. When the samples are warmed in the spectrometer, the formation of new signals in the 1H as well as the 31P{1H} NMR spectra of 2a-c can be observed above 253 K, which is caused by an increase in dynamic processes of the complex cations in solution. The 31P{1H} NMR spectra of 2a-c at 300 K can be viewed as characteristic since they do not change significantly upon the addition of E n  ligands (see below). Notably, these thermal evolutions are not reversible as upon cooling from room temperature solutions, i.e., the NMR spectra do not evolve and return to the initial pattern. This suggests equilibria of different species in solution. However, the NMR spectra of 2a and 2b at room temperature still show the initial signal patterns of the parent [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complexes (X = Cl (2a), Br (2b)) as the major species (~80%). For X = I (2c), the initial signals of [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (2c) can still be observed at room temperature, although they represent only about 50% or less of the species in solution. It has to be emphasized at this point that by following our synthetic strategy of preassembled [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks no other combination of CuX, dpmp, and [Cu+][BF4] was ever observed in the solid sate. The observed behavior can be rationalized as follows: the equilibria of different species in solution include slow transformation processes that are almost frozen at low temperatures, and during the crystallization process, these equilibria are shifted to the side of the cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex. Unfortunately, the solid-state 31P{1H} NMR spectra of parent complexes 2a-c show only one broad resonance in each case arising from several overlapping signals, and no assignment to the corresponding phosphorus atoms is possible (see Supporting Information).

elements.content: 1H and 31P­{1H} VT-NMR experiments for 2a–c from 193 to 300 K in CD2Cl2 solution. Diastereotopic H atoms HA and HB were assigned tentatively. The sharp signals on top of the broad signals in the 1H NMR spectrum of 2c arise from residual THF and Et2O from the initial synthesis of 1c. Compounds 2a–c represent a AA′A″A‴BB′ spin system, illustrated in Scheme , which results in higher-order 31P­{1H} NMR spectra.

elements.clean_text: 4  Schematic Representation of the Complex Cations of 2a-c for NMR Assignments

elements.content: The P2 complex A1 has been reported to bridge monocationic metal centers in a μ,η1:η1-mode in several compounds. Therefore, interconnection of [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks 2a–c was attempted by reacting them with an equimolar amount of E2 complexes A1 and A2. It can be noted that reaction of 2a with 2 equiv of A1 yields a molecular complex with two terminal A1 units. For the current study, ligands A1 and A2 are dissolved in a small amount of CH2Cl2 and directly added to a in situ prepared clear CH2Cl2 solution of parent trinuclear complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ 2a–c (). Diffusion of alkanes into the filtered CH2Cl2 solutions affords light red crystals of products 4a–c or dark red crystals of 5. The 1H and 31P­{1H} NMR spectra of 4a–c and 5 in CD2Cl2 solution show sets of signals that are almost identical to the signals assigned to cationinc [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complexes 2a–c. This suggests that the chemical environment of parent trinuclear complexes 2a–c is not significantly altered by coordination of the E2 ligands A1 or A2. In addition, a singlet can be observed in the 1H NMR spectra for the Cp rings of A1 or A2. The signal corresponding to the P2 ligand of A1 in the 31P­{1H} NMR spectra of 4a–c is significantly broadened and shifted to higher field (Δδ = 21 ppm for 4a, 30 ppm for 4b, and 34 ppm for 4c) compared to that of free ligand A1 (δ = −42.9 ppm).

X-ray Structural Analysis of <bold>4a</bold>–<bold>c</bold> and <bold>5</bold>

Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis () clearly reveals that compounds 4a–c and 5 have very similar structures. The compounds exhibit central [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks with no terminal ligand on Cu1, whereas Cu3 is additionally coordinated in a η1-mode by E2 complex A1 or A2. Therefore, the coordination geometry of Cu1 can be described as distorted trigonal planar, whereas Cu3 adopts a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The intermolecular Cu–Cu distances (Cu1–Cu2 and Cu2–Cu3) of each [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building block differ significantly due to the coordination of A1 and A2 to Cu3. The Cu1–Cu2 distances for all complexes 4a–c (∼2.84 Å) and 5 (3.0658(15) Å) are quite short, suggesting cuprophilic interactions, and can be compared well to the parent complex cations 2a, 2b, and 2c*. Although the Cu2–Cu3 distance is the shortest for 5 containing the As2 ligand A2 at 3.2176(1) Å, it increases in the series 4a (X = Cl), 4b (X = Br), 4c (X = I) from 3.3572(1) to 3.5190(14) Å with the increasing size of the halide. The Cu3 chains can be viewed as almost linear with Cu–Cu–Cu angles between 160 and 164°, which are not significantly changed compared to those of 2a–c*. The Cu3–P1 as well as the P1–P2 bond lengths of 4a–c are identical, ∼2.36 Å (Cu3–P1) and ∼2.08 Å (P1–P2, 2.079(2) Å for free A1). The As–As distance in 5 (2.3097(1) Å) is also unchanged compared to that of free A2 (2.305(3) Å). In conclusion, the introduction of E2 complexes A1 and A2 to the preassembled [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks did not afford an interconnection, but 4a–c and 5 can be obtained as the only products by crystallization without the formation of any other isomers or different combinations of the starting materials in the solid state. Complexes 4a–5 can all be recrystallized without alteration of the assemblies in the solid state.

All of the above-described compounds, 1a–5, demonstrate that the intramolecular Cu–Cu distances are drastically affected upon coordination of any ligand to the terminal Cu atoms. Because compounds 4a–5 represent the first unsymmetrically substituted [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks, it is of interest to investigate the geometrical effects induced by coordination of only one terminal ligand. Therefore, we performed DFT calculations on the model compound [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dmmp)2(η1-A1)]+ (4a′) (dmmp = bis­(dimethyl­phosphinomethylene)-methylphosphine) (restrained geometry optimizations). a shows the relative energy of the model compound 4a′ with the variation of the Cu3–P1 distance (labeled according to 4a). The calculations reveal a minimum at a Cu3–P1 bond length around 2.35 Å, which is in good agreement with the determined X-ray structure of 4a. b shows the evolution of the intramolecular Cu–Cu distances (Cu1–Cu2 and Cu2–Cu3) as well as the Cu3–Cl1 distance as the Cu3–P1 distance varies. From this graph, it can be clearly seen that the approach of the P1 atom of A1 toward the Cu3 atom induces a drastic increase in the adjacent Cu3–Cu2 distance, whereas the Cu1–Cu2 distance is not changed at all. The Cu3–Cl1 distance is only slightly affected.

elements.content: The E2 ligands A1 and A2 did not afford an interconnection of [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks 2a–c to form coordination polymers. However, it was possible to obtain the isolated complexes 4a–c and 5 from these reactions. In order to realize the connection of 2a–c via P n ligand complexes, the less sterically demanding cyclo-P3 complex B was introduced. Complexes A1 and B are closely related, and their analogous nature can be easily described by exchanging one 15 VE complex fragment [CpMo­(CO)2] of A1 for an isolobal P atom in B (). Complex B was added to in situ prepared clear colorless CH2Cl2 solutions of 2a–c in an equimolar ratio (). The clear yellow solutions were stirred and subsequently filtered. Diffusion of alkanes into these solutions afforded clear yellow needles of 6a (X = Cl) and yellow blocks of 6b (X = Br) or 7 (X = I). Subsequent analysis of 7 by single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed a 1:2 stoichiometry of the [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building block and complex B, and the synthesis was subsequently reproduced at this ratio to afford 7 as the only product. The 1H and 31P­{1H} NMR spectra of 6a, 6b, and 7 in CD2Cl2 suggest dissociation in solution and show characteristic signals for the cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex. The 1H NMR spectra of 6a, 6b, and 7 show an additional singlet for the Cp ring of B. The 31P­{1H} NMR spectra in CD2Cl2 solution reveal an additional sharp singlet at δ = −350.7 ppm (6a), −350.7 ppm (6b), and −351.2 ppm (7) that is almost identical to that of free complex B (δ = −351.1 ppm).

X-ray Structural Analysis of <bold>6a</bold>, <bold>6b</bold>, and <bold>7</bold>

Single-crystal X-ray structure determination (a,b) revealed an isostructural one-dimensional polymeric structure of compounds 6a (X = Cl) and 6b (X = Br) in which the central [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks are connected by a cyclo-P3 ligand of complex B bridging in a η1:η1-coordination mode. Coordination polymers 6a and 6b describe a zigzag chain with alternating orientations of the [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks. Surprisingly, the structure of 7 shows a finite complex cation consisting of a central [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building block terminated by an η1-coordinating cyclo-P3 complex on each end instead of a coordination polymer (c). The intramolecular Cu–Cu distances of 6a, 6b, and 7 are all greater than 3.17 Å and increase with the increasing size of the bridging halide up to ∼3.44 Å for 7. The Cu–P bond lengths of the terminal Cu atoms to the P atom of complex B are not identical on both sides of the [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks, with average values ranging from 2.35 to 2.45 Å. The Cu–Cu–Cu angles are between 162 and 167°. In conclusion, cyclo-P3 complex B facilitates the interconnection of the preassembled [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks (for X = Cl, Br), whereas it acts as a terminal η1-ligand toward [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+. Although dissociation takes place in solution, 6a, 6b, and 7 can be obtained as the only products by crystallization without observing any other isomers or different combinations of the starting materials in the solid state. All complexes 6a–7 can be recrystallized without alteration of the assemblies in the solid state.

After successful characterization of finite coordination compounds 4a–c, 5, and 7 and one-dimensional coordination polymers 6a and 6b from reactions with E2 and cyclo-P3 ligand complexes, subsequently, larger cyclo-E5 complexes C1 and C2 () were introduced to the preassembled [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks. Therefore, C1 or C2 was added to an in situ prepared clear colorless CH2Cl2 solutions of 2a–c in an equimolar ratio (). The clear green (E = P) or brown (E = As) solutions were stirred for an additional 24 h. After filtration and subsequent alkane diffusion into these solutions, compounds 8a, 8b, and 10 can be isolated as rod-like green crystals, whereas 9 crystallizes as brown blocks. Analysis of 10 by single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed a 1:2 stoichiometry of the [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building block and complex C1. The synthesis was subsequently reproduced at this ratio to afford pure 10. X-ray Structural Analysis of <bold>8a</bold>, <bold>8b</bold>, <bold>9</bold>, and <bold>10</bold>

Single-crystal X-ray structure determination reveals isostructural one-dimensional coordination polymers of 8a, 8b, and 9 (a–c) with alternating [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks (8a, 9: X = Cl; 8b: X = Br) and bridging σ-1,3-coordinating cyclo-E5 ligand complexes (8a, 8b: E = P; 9: E = As). This bridging coordination mode has been described previously for C1 toward CuI centers but was unprecedented for C2 prior to the characterization of 9. Two consecutive [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks along the one-dimensional polymeric chain are rotated by roughly 90°. In contrast, the crystal structure of 10 shows a finite complex cation with a central [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building block and two terminal η1-coordinating cyclo-P5 complexes C1 (cf. cyclo-P3 complexes B in 7). The intramolecular Cu–Cu distances inside the Cu3 units coordinated to cyclo-P5 complex C1 are all greater than 3.29 Å and increase with the increasing size of the bridging halide in the order 8a, 8b, 10 from 3.2975(1) to 3.612(3) Å. The isostructural one-dimensional polymer 9 containing cyclo-As5 complex C2 instead exhibits the shortest Cu–Cu distances in this series, 3.0345(1) and 3.2135(1) Å, respectively. The Cu–Cu–Cu angles of one-dimensional polymers 8a, 8b, and 9 are similar and between 168 and 169°. In contrast, complex 10 exhibits a Cu–Cu–Cu angle of only 159.62(8)°. In conclusion, cyclo-P5 complex C1 facilitates the interconnection of the preassembled [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks (for X = Cl, Br). Surprisingly, cyclo-As5 complex C2 shows the same connectivity toward [Cu3(μ-Cl)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ in the crystal structure of 9; however, this results in shorter intermolecular Cu–Cu distances than those observed for the analogous cyclo-P5 polymer 8a. In the case of the iodine-bridged [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building block, a discrete complex featuring two η1-coordinating cyclo-P5 ligands C1 is formed. Although the obtained products of the [Cu3(μ-Cl)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks and cyclo-E5 complexes C1 and C2 dissociate in solution, they can be isolated as the only products by crystallization without the formation of any other isomers or different combinations of the starting materials in the solid state. All complexes 8a–10 can be recrystallized without alteration of the assemblies in the solid state.

In contrast, the crystal structure of 10 shows a finite complex cation with a central [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building block and two terminal η1-coordinating cyclo-P5 complexes C1 (cf. cyclo-P3 complexes B in 7). The intramolecular Cu-Cu distances inside the Cu3 units coordinated to cyclo-P5 complex C1 are all greater than 3.29 Å and increase with the increasing size of the bridging halide in the order 8a, 8b, 10 from 3.2975(1) to 3.612(3) Å. The isostructural one-dimensional polymer 9 containing cyclo-As5 complex C2 instead exhibits the shortest Cu-Cu distances in this series, 3.0345(1) and 3.2135(1) Å, respectively. The Cu-Cu-Cu angles of one-dimensional polymers 8a, 8b, and 9 are similar and between 168 and 169°. In contrast, complex 10 exhibits a Cu-Cu-Cu angle of only 159.62(8)°. In conclusion, cyclo-P5 complex C1 facilitates the interconnection of the preassembled [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks (for X = Cl, Br). Surprisingly, cyclo-As5 complex C2 shows the same connectivity toward [Cu3(μ-Cl)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ in the crystal structure of 9; however, this results in shorter intermolecular Cu-Cu distances than those observed for the analogous cyclo-P5 polymer 8a. In the case of the iodine-bridged [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building block, a discrete complex featuring two η1-coordinating cyclo-P5 ligands C1 is formed. Although the obtained products of the [Cu3(μ-Cl)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks and cyclo-E5 complexes C1 and C2 dissociate in solution, they can be isolated as the only products by crystallization without the formation of any other isomers or different combinations of the starting materials in the solid state. All complexes 8a-10 can be recrystallized without alteration of the assemblies in the solid state.

All described compounds 1a–10 contain cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks in their crystal structures. (vide supra) summarizes the intermolecular Cu–Cu distances as well as the distances to the respective donor atoms of the terminal ligands. The presented data clearly shows the direct influence of the coordination to the terminal Cu atoms on the adjacent Cu–Cu distances. The shortest Cu–Cu distances, which are in the range of d10–d10 metallophilic interactions, are observed for 2a–2c* that exhibit no terminal ligands and two Cu atoms in distorted trigonal planar coordination geometry. An elongation of the Cu–Cu distances takes place if any ligand is introduced on the terminal Cu atoms. This phenomenon is observed even for the very weakly coordinating ligand CH2Cl2 in 3b and 3c. Structural analysis of 4a–c and 5 clearly shows that coordination to only one end of the [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks results only in the elongation of the adjacent Cu–Cu distance, whereas the other is not affected and resembles the short Cu–Cu distances of 2a–2c*. When the same ligands are coordinated on both sides of the Cu3 units (1a–c, 3b, 3c, and 6a–10), their direct comparison allows the following conclusion to be made: As the bond length to the terminal ligand (Cu–E) becomes shorter, the respective adjacent Cu–Cu distance inside the Cu3 unit will become longer. Whether this elongation is caused by either electronic effects via termination of any possible metallophilic d10–d10 interactions or just by a change of the coordination environment of the terminal Cu atoms from trigonal planar to tetrahedral cannot be clearly answered at this point. Similar studies on the alteration of Cr–Cr distances upon coordination of different terminal ligands have been carried out for trinuclear Cr EMACs.

elements.content: The highly feasible and selective preparation of trinuclear [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks and their potential use in supramolecular chemistry are described. Reactions with selected E n ligand complexes and full characterization of the products demonstrated the following: (1) Although some of the characterized products exhibit finite complex cations, the used E n ligand complexes are confirmed to be valuable linking moieties for supramolecular chemistry, which are so far dominated by organic O, N, and S donors. (2) The framework of the preassembled cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex is stable toward the introduction of varying E n ligand complexes. Additionally, although all of the described syntheses are based on self-assembly of multicomponent systems, the reactions proceed very selectively and no formation of any side product was observed. A comparison of the intramolecular Cu–Cu distances inside the cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex for all compounds demonstrates that coordination to the terminal Cu atoms results in an elongation of the adjacent aforementioned Cu–Cu distances. This behavior is supported by DFT computations for the model complex [Cu3(μ-Cl)2(dmmp)2{(η1-A1)}]+ (4a′). We expect that synthetic approaches via self-assembly based on the presented findings will lead to a wide variety of supramolecular coordination compounds containing readily available [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks in the near future. Future investigations include the determination of the photophysical properties of the cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complexes and their adducts.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The highly feasible and selective preparation of trinuclear [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks and their potential use in supramolecular chemistry are described. Reactions with selected E n  ligand complexes and full characterization of the products demonstrated the following: (1) Although some of the characterized products exhibit finite complex cations, the used E n  ligand complexes are confirmed to be valuable linking moieties for supramolecular chemistry, which are so far dominated by organic O, N, and S donors. (2) The framework of the preassembled cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex is stable toward the introduction of varying E n  ligand complexes. Additionally, although all of the described syntheses are based on self-assembly of multicomponent systems, the reactions proceed very selectively and no formation of any side product was observed. A comparison of the intramolecular Cu-Cu distances inside the cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex for all compounds demonstrates that coordination to the terminal Cu atoms results in an elongation of the adjacent aforementioned Cu-Cu distances. This behavior is supported by DFT computations for the model complex [Cu3(μ-Cl)2(dmmp)2{(η1-A1)}]+ (4a'). We expect that synthetic approaches via self-assembly based on the presented findings will lead to a wide variety of supramolecular coordination compounds containing readily available [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building blocks in the near future. Future investigations include the determination of the photophysical properties of the cationic [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complexes and their adducts.

elements.content: All described compounds exhibit a central [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ building block in their solid state structures. Polyphosphine ligand dpmp stabilizes the arrangement. The resulting Cu–P distances of the dpmp ligand are all within the expected range of 2.2–2.3 Å for coordination of phosphines to CuI and will not be discussed in detail. The reported Cu–P distances exclusively relate to the coordination of the P n ligand complexes to the terminal Cu atoms.

The resulting Cu-P distances of the dpmp ligand are all within the expected range of 2.2-2.3 Å for coordination of phosphines to CuI and will not be discussed in detail. The reported Cu-P distances exclusively relate to the coordination of the P n  ligand complexes to the terminal Cu atoms.

elements.content: All manipulations were carried out under an inert atmosphere of dried nitrogen using standard Schlenk and dry box techniques. THF was dried with Na. MeCN, CH2Cl2, and CD2Cl2 were dried over CaH2. o-DFB was distilled from P4O10. NMR spectra were recorded in CD2Cl2 on a Bruker Avance 300 MHz NMR spectrometer (1H: 300.132 MHz; 31P: 121.495 MHz; 13C: 75.468 MHz; 19F: 282.404 MHz) or on a Bruker Avance 400 MHz NMR spectrometer (1H: 400.130 MHz; 31P: 161.976 MHz; 13C: 100.613 MHz; 11B: 128.378 MHz) with external references of SiMe4 (1H, 13C), CCl3F (19F), H3PO4 (85%, 31P), or Et2O·BF3 (11B). IR spectra were recorded as KBr discs using a Varian FTS-800 FT-IR spectrometer. Electron spray ionization mass spectra were recorded by the MS department of the University of Regensburg on a ThermoQuest Finnigan TSQ 7000 mass spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed by the micro analytical laboratory of the University of Regensburg. Commercially available reagents were used without further purification. CuI halides were recrystallized from MeCN prior to use. E n ligand complexes A1, A2, B, C1, and C2 as well as the dpmp ligand were prepared according to literature procedures with minor alterations. The preparation and full characterization of compounds 1a, 2a*, 4a, 5, 8a, and 9 were reported previously.

IR spectra were recorded as KBr discs using a Varian FTS-800 FT-IR spectrometer. Electron spray ionization mass spectra were recorded by the MS department of the University of Regensburg on a ThermoQuest Finnigan TSQ 7000 mass spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed by the micro analytical laboratory of the University of Regensburg. Commercially available reagents were used without further purification. CuI halides were recrystallized from MeCN prior to use. E n  ligand complexes A1, A2, B, C1, and C2  as well as the dpmp ligand were prepared according to literature procedures with minor alterations. elements.content: All calculations were performed with the TURBOMOLE program package. The geometry was optimized using the RI-B3LYP functional together with the def2-SVP basis set for all atoms. The multipole accelerated resolution of identity (MARI-J) approximation was used through the geometry optimization steps. The dispersion effects were incorporated by using Grimme’s D3 method. The restrained geometry optimization of model compound 4a′ was performed by keeping the Cu3–P1 distance fixed while all other parameters were optimized.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

All calculations were performed with the TURBOMOLE program package. The geometry was optimized using the RI-B3LYP functional together with the def2-SVP basis set for all atoms. The multipole accelerated resolution of identity (MARI-J) approximation was used through the geometry optimization steps. The dispersion effects were incorporated by using Grimme's D3 method. The restrained geometry optimization of model compound 4a' was performed by keeping the Cu3-P1 distance fixed while all other parameters were optimized.

References

Parent compounds 2a–c can exhibit two different isomers with respect to the orientation of the central Ph group of one dpmp ligand (see below for details), which are referred to as 2a–c and 2a*–c*. This isomerism was observed only for the parent compounds with vacant coordination sites on the terminal atoms. During this study, no single-crystal structures of 2c and 2a* could be determined.

References

Parent compounds 2a-c can exhibit two different isomers with respect to the orientation of the central Ph group of one dpmp ligand (see below for details), which are referred to as 2a-c and 2a*-c*. This isomerism was observed only for the parent compounds with vacant coordination sites on the terminal atoms. During this study, no single-crystal structures of 2c and 2a* could be determined.

elements.content:
The analogue complex for X = Cl (3a) could not be structurally characterized.

The crystal structure of 1a is in good agreement with the determined structure of the previously reported [ClO4]− salt. See ref .

Although the central Ph rings in 2a and 2b are directed upward in , they are directed toward the reader in 2c* and 2a* in and .

The dynamic coordination behavior of [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (see ) is the reason that in solution only ∼50% of the parent Cu3 building block is present next to other species. Therefore, we assume that this trinuclear complex readily reacts with cyclo-P3 ligand B to form compound 7 with a 1:2 ratio instead of the analogous polymeric 6c with a 1:2 ratio. When a solution of a 1:1 stoichiometry (2c/B) is kept for a long time, the formation of 7 (1:1 ratio) can be seen followed by the formation of colorless crystals after some time (presumably pure 2c). Similar behavior is observed in the reaction of 2c with cyclo-P5 complex C1. For this reaction, we have some indications that we can actually prepare the analogous compound with a 1:1 ratio (2c/C1) (see below).

elements.content: Crystals of 6a could be obtained only as very fine needles that lose their crystallinity immediately after removal from the mother liquor even when mounted in cooled oil. This significantly complicated the data collection and structure refinement. The unit cell and space group were assigned to P21; a = 14.7809(3) Å, b = 20.9944(4) Å, c = 15.7059(3) Å, β = 95.416(2)°, and V = 4852.04(16) Å3. The final model for this structure determination (R = 4.0%, wR2 = 10.8%) clearly shows a similar arrangement of 6a and 6b in the solid state (the structure solution and refinement of 6b could be done without difficulty).

elements.content: The reactivity of C1 toward 2c closely resembles the reactivity of complex B. We assume that this result occurs for the same reasons (see ref ), which are based on the dynamic coordination behavior of 2c in solution. When 2c is dissolved at −30 °C (see VT-NMR study; NMR shows that almost 100% of the compound is present as the parent [Cu3(μ-I)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ complex) and reacted with an equimolar amount of C1, very tiny light green crystals are obtained upon diffusion of alkanes into this solution. X-ray diffraction allows the determination of a unit cell (monoclinic P; a = 12.4819(19) Å, b = 25.128(3), c = 27.818(7) Å, β = 97.68(2), V = 8647(3), 95.12% indexed, and 164 reflections collected), but the diffraction was too weak to enable structure determination. This unit cell is in good agreement with the determined unit cells of the three isostructural one-dimensional coordination polymers 8a, 8b, and 9. This conclusively suggests the formation of the analogous polymeric compound 8c, although we were unable to structurally characterize it.

cln_elements.content:
When the reactants (2 equiv of CuX (X = Cl, Br, I), 2 equiv of dpmp, and 1 equiv of [Cu­(MeCN)4]­[BF4]) are suspended in pure CH2Cl2 or ortho-difluorobenzene (o-DFB) and stirred at room temperature, the formation of clear colorless solutions can be observed after 5 min (X = Cl), 30 min (X = Br), or 5–6 h (X = I). Subsequent diffusion of alkanes into the filtered solution yields parent trinuclear complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (X = Cl (2a), Br (2b), I (2c)) as colorless crystals in good yields (65–75%). Additionally, [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(CH2Cl2)2]+ (X = Br (3b), I (3c)) (identified by single-crystal X-ray structural analysis), which show two terminal η1-coordinating CH2Cl2 molecules, could also be observed from these reactions. These CH2Cl2 solvent molecules are removed by drying the crystals.

Preparation of [Cu<sub>3</sub>(μ-Br)<sub>2</sub>(dpmp)<sub>2</sub>(MeCN)<sub>2</sub>]<sup>+</sup>[BF<sub>4</sub>]<sup>−</sup> (<bold>1b</bold>)

101 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of dpmp, 32 mg (1 equiv, 0.1 mmol) of [Cu­(MeCN)4]­[BF4], and 29 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of CuBr were weighed into a Schlenk flask, and a solvent mixture of 8 mL of THF and 2 mL of MeCN was added under constant stirring. The compounds dissolved to form a clear and colorless solution. After 24 h of stirring at room temperature, the solution was filtered and subsequently layered with a 5-fold amount of Et2O. Storage at +4 °C afforded colorless crystals over the course of some days. The mother liquor was decanted off of the crystals. The crystals were washed with Et2O a few times and dried in vacuum for 30 min. After this time, the coordinated MeCN ligands were removed from the crystals, as proved by elemental analysis. Therefore, the recorded NMR spectra correspond to 2b. Yield 116 mg (76%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD2Cl2, 193 K) δ/ppm 8.34–6.12 (multiple signals, 50H, Ph), 3.60 (br, 4H, CH2), 3.17 (br, 4H, CH2); 31P­{1H} NMR (162.0 MHz, CD2Cl2, 193 K) δ/ppm −16.7 (m, 4P, RPPh2), −21.5 (br, 2P, R2PPh); 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD2Cl2, 300 K) δ/ppm 7.87–6.57 (m, 50H, Ph), 3.85–3.07 (multiple overlapping signals, CH2); 31P­{1H} NMR (162.0 MHz, CD2Cl2, 300 K) δ/ppm −6.5 (m, small signal), −12.1 (m, small signal), −15.9 (m, RPPh2), −21.5 (br, R2PPh); 11B­{1H} NMR (128.4 MHz, CD2Cl2, 300 K) δ/ppm −0.91 (BF4); 13C­{1H} NMR (100.6 MHz, CD2Cl2, 300 K) δ/ppm 135.32–127.65 (multiple signals, Ph), 31.05–28.76 (CH2). Anal. Calcd for C64H58BBr2Cu3F4P6: C, 53.00; H, 4.03. Found: C, 53.17; H, 4.09. Coordinated MeCN was removed by drying. Positive ion MS, m/q (%): 1363.2(100) [Cu3Br2(dpmp)2]+, 1319.3(17) [Cu3BrCl­(dpmp)2]+, 713.0(13) [Cu2Br­(dpmp)]+, 642.2(10) [Cu3Br­(dpmp)2]2+, 569.0(8) [Cu­(dpmp)]+. Negative ion MS, m/q (%): 87.1(100) [BF4]−. IR (KBr) cm–1: 3072 (w), 3052 (w), 3021 (vw), 3005 (vw), 2987 (vw), 2925 (vw), 2897 (vw), 2361 (w), 2333 (w), 1624 (w), 1587 (w), 1574 (w), 1484 (m), 1435 (s), 1384 (w), 1124 (m), 1097 (s), 1084 (vs), 1064 (m), 1028 (m), 1000 (w).

The compounds dissolved to form a clear and colorless solution. After 24 h of stirring at room temperature, the solution was filtered and subsequently layered with a 5-fold amount of Et2O. The crystals were washed with Et2O a few times and dried in vacuum for 30 min. After this time, the coordinated MeCN ligands were removed from the crystals, as proved by elemental analysis. Therefore, the recorded NMR spectra correspond to 2c. Preparation of [Cu<sub>3</sub>(μ-Br)<sub>2</sub>(dpmp)<sub>2</sub>(CH<sub>2</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]<sup>+</sup>[BF<sub>4</sub>]<sup>−</sup> (<bold>3b</bold>) and [Cu<sub>3</sub>(μ-Br)<sub>2</sub>(dpmp)<sub>2</sub>]<sup>+</sup>[BF<sub>4</sub>]<sup>−</sup> (<bold>2b</bold>)

101 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of dpmp, 32 mg (1 equiv, 0.1 mmol) of [Cu­(MeCN)4]­[BF4], and 29 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of CuBr were weighed into a Schlenk flask, 10 mL of CH2Cl2 (3) or 50 mL of o-DFB (2b) was added, and the reaction was stirred for 24 h. The compounds dissolved to form a clear and colorless solution in ∼30 min. After 24 h of stirring at room temperature, the solution was filtered and subsequent layering with a 5-fold amount of n-hexane (2b) or gas-phase diffusion of n-pentane into the solution (3) afforded product 2b or 3 as clear colorless crystals over the course of some days. The mother liquor was decanted off of the crystals. The crystals were washed with alkanes a few times and dried in vacuum for 30 min. Yield 97 mg (3, 67%). For analytical data, see the preparation of 1b.

Preparation of [Cu<sub>3</sub>(μ-I)<sub>2</sub>(dpmp)<sub>2</sub>]<sup>+</sup>[BF<sub>4</sub>]<sup>−</sup> (<bold>2c</bold>)

101 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of dpmp, 32 mg (1 equiv, 0.1 mmol) of [Cu­(MeCN)4]­[BF4], and 38 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of CuI were weighed into a Schlenk flask, 10 mL of CH2Cl2 was added, and the reaction was stirred for 24 h. The compounds dissolved to form a clear and colorless solution over the course of 5–6 h. After 24 h of stirring at room temperature, the solution was filtered and subsequent gas-phase diffusion of n-pentane into the solution afforded 2c as clear colorless crystals over the course of some days. The mother liquor was decanted off of the crystals. The crystals were washed with n-pentane a few times and dried in vacuum for 30 min. Yield 107 mg (69%). For analytical data, see the preparation of 1c.

Preparation of [Cu<sub>3</sub>(μ-Br)<sub>2</sub>(dpmp)<sub>2</sub>(η<sup>1</sup>-<bold>A1</bold>)]<sup>+</sup>[BF<sub>4</sub>]<sup>−</sup> (<bold>4b</bold>)

101 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of dpmp, 32 mg (1 equiv, 0.1 mmol) of [Cu­(MeCN)4]­[BF4], and 29 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of CuBr were weighed into a Schlenk flask, and 10 mL of CH2Cl2 was added. The solids dissolved under constant stirring over the course of 30 min to form a clear colorless solution. After 24 h of stirring at room temperature, 50 mg (1 equiv, 0.1 mmol) of A1 was added, and the clear red solution was stirred for an additional 24 h. Vapor diffusion of n-pentane into the filtered solution at room temperature afforded 4b as orange needles after several days. The crystals were separated from the mother liquor, washed with n-pentane a few times, and dried in vacuum. Negative ion MS, m/q (%): 1537.2(100) [Cu3Br2(dpmp)2(BF4)2]−, 1491.3(14) [Cu3BrCl­(dpmp)2(BF4)2]−. IR (KBr) cm–1: 3118 (vw), 3080 (vw), 3052 (w), 3005 (vw), 2987 (vw), 2951 (vw), 2894 (vw), 1990 (w), 1964 (vs), 1924 (s), 1911 (s), 1630 (w), 1485 (w), 1435 (m), 1419 (w), 1378 (w), 1098 (m), 1084 (m), 1027 (w), 1000 (w).

Direct Synthesis of 2a-c 

When the reactants (2 equiv of CuX (X = Cl, Br, I), 2 equiv of dpmp, and 1 equiv of [Cu(MeCN)4][BF4]) are suspended in pure CH2Cl2 or ortho-difluorobenzene (o-DFB) and stirred at room temperature, the formation of clear colorless solutions can be observed after 5 min (X = Cl), 30 min (X = Br), or 5-6 h (X = I). Subsequent diffusion of alkanes into the filtered solution yields parent trinuclear complexes [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2]+ (X = Cl (2a), Br (2b), I (2c)) as colorless crystals in good yields (65-75%). Additionally, [Cu3(μ-X)2(μ-dpmp)2(CH2Cl2)2]+ (X = Br (3b), I (3c)) (identified by single-crystal X-ray structural analysis), which show two terminal η1-coordinating CH2Cl2 molecules, could also be observed from these reactions. These CH2Cl2 solvent molecules are removed by drying the crystals.

Preparation of [Cu3(μ-Br)2(dpmp)2(MeCN)2]+[BF4]- (1b)

101 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of dpmp, 32 mg (1 equiv, 0.1 mmol) of [Cu(MeCN)4][BF4], and 29 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of CuBr were weighed into a Schlenk flask, and a solvent mixture of 8 mL of THF and 2 mL of MeCN was added under constant stirring. The compounds dissolved to form a clear and colorless solution. After 24 h of stirring at room temperature, the solution was filtered and subsequently layered with a 5-fold amount of Et2O. Storage at +4 °C afforded colorless crystals over the course of some days. The mother liquor was decanted off of the crystals. The crystals were washed with Et2O a few times and dried in vacuum for 30 min. After this time, the coordinated MeCN ligands were removed from the crystals, as proved by elemental analysis. Therefore, the recorded NMR spectra correspond to 2b. Yield 116 mg (76%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD2Cl2, 193 K) δ/ppm 8.34-6.12 (multiple signals, 50H, Ph), 3.60 (br, 4H, CH2), 3.17 (br, 4H, CH2); 31P{1H} NMR (162.0 MHz, CD2Cl2, 193 K) δ/ppm -16.7 (m, 4P, RPPh2), -21.5 (br, 2P, R2PPh); 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD2Cl2, 300 K) δ/ppm 7.87-6.57 (m, 50H, Ph), 3.85-3.07 (multiple overlapping signals, CH2); 31P{1H} NMR (162.0 MHz, CD2Cl2, 300 K) δ/ppm -6.5 (m, small signal), -12.1 (m, small signal), -15.9 (m, RPPh2), -21.5 (br, R2PPh); 11B{1H} NMR (128.4 MHz, CD2Cl2, 300 K) δ/ppm -0.91 (BF4); 13C{1H} NMR (100.6 MHz, CD2Cl2, 300 K) δ/ppm 135.32-127.65 (multiple signals, Ph), 31.05-28.76 (CH2). Anal. Calcd for C64H58BBr2Cu3F4P6: C, 53.00; H, 4.03. Found: C, 53.17; H, 4.09. Coordinated MeCN was removed by drying. Positive ion MS, m/q (%): 1363.2(100) [Cu3Br2(dpmp)2]+, 1319.3(17) [Cu3BrCl(dpmp)2]+, 713.0(13) [Cu2Br(dpmp)]+, 642.2(10) [Cu3Br(dpmp)2]2+, 569.0(8) [Cu(dpmp)]+. Negative ion MS, m/q (%): 87.1(100) [BF4]-. Negative ion MS, m/q (%): 1537.4(100) [Cu3Br2(dpmp)2(BF4)2]-, 1493.4(14) [Cu3BrCl(dpmp)2(BF4)2]-, 1681.2(13) [Cu4Br3(dpmp)2(BF4)2]-. IR (KBr) cm-1: 3118 (vw), 3072 (vw), 3050 (w), 3005 (vw), 2987 (vw), 2949 (vw), 2917 (vw), 2891 (vw), 2850 (vw), 2361 (w), 2342 (w), 2018 (vs), 1956 (vs), 1636 (m), 1484 (m), 1435 (vs), 1420 (w), 1384 (w), 1124 (m), 1098 (s), 1084 (vs), 1028 (m), 1000 (m).

Preparation of [Cu3(μ-I)2(dpmp)2(η1-B)2]+[BF4]- (7)

101 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of dpmp, 32 mg (1 equiv, 0.1 mmol) of [Cu(MeCN)4][BF4], and 38 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of CuI were weighed into a Schlenk flask, and 10 mL of CH2Cl2 was added. The solids dissolved under constant stirring over the course of 5-6 h to form a clear colorless solution. After 24 h of stirring at room temperature, 62 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of B was added, and the clear yellow solution was stirred for an additional 24 h. The solution was filtered, carefully layered with pristine CH2Cl2 (~5 mL), and subsequently layered with a 5-fold amount of n-pentane. Storage at +4 °C afforded 7 as yellow blocks after some days. The mother liquor was decanted, and the crystals were washed with n-pentane a few times and dried in vacuum. Negative ion MS, m/q (%): 87.3(100) [BF4]-. 101 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of dpmp, 32 mg (1 equiv, 0.1 mmol) of [Cu(MeCN)4][BF4], and 29 mg (2 equiv, 0.2 mmol) of CuBr were weighed into a Schlenk flask, and 10 mL of CH2Cl2 was added. cln_elements.content:
Linear Metal Chains Featuring Various Supporting Ligands<xref rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

(I) Model complexes of linear transition metal arrays supported by polypyridylamide ligands, (II) Pd chains sandwiched by conjugated polyene molecules, (III) polymetallic Ag+ and Au+ clusters stabilized by polyphosphine ligands, and (IV) multinuclear CuI chains stabilized by polyphosphine ligands and bridging halides.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Linear Metal Chains Featuring Various Supporting Ligands      a (I) Model complexes of linear transition metal arrays supported by polypyridylamide ligands, (II) Pd chains sandwiched by conjugated polyene molecules, (III) polymetallic Ag+ and Au+ clusters stabilized by polyphosphine ligands, and (IV) multinuclear CuI chains stabilized by polyphosphine ligands and bridging halides.
